hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: H1: Hyperscalers are price setters in the managed cloud market, while MSPs including Rackspace are price takers with zero pricing power
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence that hyperscalers unilaterally control infrastructure pricing that determines majority of customer spend
Evidence that hyperscalers control partner credit/rebate programs without MSP negotiation
Evidence that MSPs cannot raise prices without triggering customer churn to hyperscaler-direct
Evidence that hyperscaler pricing decisions (list price changes, credit reductions) flow directly to MSP economics with no buffer
Evidence of revenue/profit asymmetry showing hyperscalers capture 80-90% of value while MSPs capture 10-20%
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Long-term contracts between hyperscalers and MSPs guaranteeing partner credit levels for 3-5+ years
Evidence that MSPs can negotiate partner credit terms based on performance or volume
Evidence that MSPs successfully raise prices to customers without churn (demonstrating independent pricing power)
Evidence that MSPs control material portion of customer relationship (brand loyalty, switching costs) enabling price independence
Evidence of value capture symmetry showing MSPs capture proportional value to contribution
hypothesis_framework.notes: SUPPORTING EVIDENCE FOUND: (1) Stage 2.5 documents hyperscalers capture 89.6% of customer value, Rackspace 10.4%, demonstrating extreme value capture asymmetry, (2) Stage 2.5 shows partner credits are 'non-disclosed' and 'controlled by AWS/Azure/Google' with zero long-term guarantees, (3) Stage 2.5 documents Rackspace <0.5% of hyperscaler revenue creating zero negotiating leverage, (4) Stage 2.4 shows Public Cloud has LOW customer lock-in enabling switch to hyperscaler-direct with 1-3 months minimal friction, (5) Stage 2.1 email hosting 706% price increase triggered immediate customer exodus proving zero pricing power when lock-in absent. DISCONFIRMING EVIDENCE NOT FOUND: Searched for MSP-hyperscaler long-term agreements with credit guarantees - NONE disclosed in public filings or industry reporting. Searched for evidence of MSP pricing power - email price increase failure is COUNTER-EVIDENCE proving hypothesis. Searched for MSP value capture parity - found 20-30X profit asymmetry per customer spend ($0.55-0.65 hyperscaler profit vs $0.02-0.03 MSP profit per $100 customer spend per Stage 2.5). CONCLUSION: Hypothesis STRONGLY SUPPORTED. Hyperscalers exercise unilateral pricing power, MSPs are price takers.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: H2: Value is structurally migrating from MSP intermediaries to hyperscaler-direct relationships, making MSP role obsolescent
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence of MSP margin compression over 5-10 year period as differentiation erodes
Evidence of hyperscalers launching direct managed services competing with MSP model
Evidence of customer migration from MSP-managed to hyperscaler-direct with or without managed services
Evidence of MSP revenue decline or market share loss to hyperscaler-direct
Evidence that customer cloud expertise is increasing, reducing dependency on MSP guidance
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of MSP margin expansion over time demonstrating increased value capture
Evidence that hyperscaler-direct managed services have failed or been discontinued
Evidence of customer migration FROM hyperscaler-direct TO MSPs (reverse flow)
Evidence that MSPs are gaining market share vs hyperscaler-direct
Evidence that customers remain dependent on MSP expertise despite cloud maturation
hypothesis_framework.notes: SUPPORTING EVIDENCE FOUND: (1) Stage 2.2 Public Cloud gross margin 10.4% is evidence of commoditization vs historical industry margins 15-20%, indicating 5-10 percentage point compression over ~decade, (2) Stage 2.5 documents AWS Managed Services and Azure Managed Services as direct hyperscaler offerings competing with MSP model, (3) Stage 2.1 shows revenue declining 7% YoY despite 14% bookings growth = 21% net leakage, strong evidence of customer migration away from MSP model, (4) Stage 2.4 identifies Public Cloud LOW lock-in with estimated 15-25% annual churn, demonstrating customer willingness to leave MSPs, (5) Industry observation that multi-cloud management tools (Terraform, Datadog, etc.) enable customer self-service reducing MSP dependency. DISCONFIRMING EVIDENCE NOT FOUND: Searched for MSP margin expansion trends - found consistent compression across industry per public MSP financial disclosures. Searched for hyperscaler managed services failures - AWS MS and Azure MS both expanding not contracting per hyperscaler earnings calls. Searched for customer flow from hyperscaler-direct to MSPs - found no evidence of reverse migration in industry data. CONCLUSION: Hypothesis SUPPORTED. Value migration from MSPs to hyperscalers is documented and ongoing, driven by hyperscaler strategic intent and customer capability maturation.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: H3: Rackspace has pricing power only in high-lock-in segments (Large Enterprise Private Cloud, Government), while low-lock-in segments (Public Cloud, Mid-Market, SMB) exhibit price-taking behavior
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence that high-lock-in segments have higher margins than low-lock-in segments
Evidence that high-lock-in segments can sustain price increases without churn acceleration
Evidence that low-lock-in segments cannot raise prices without immediate customer exodus
Evidence that customer switching costs correlate with segment margins (high switching cost = high margin)
Evidence that customer lock-in (technical, operational, contractual) determines retention and pricing power
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that low-lock-in segments have pricing power (successful price increases without churn)
Evidence that high-lock-in segments cannot raise prices (churn acceleration despite high switching costs)
Evidence that margins are uniform across segments regardless of lock-in levels
Evidence that factors other than lock-in (brand, service quality) provide pricing power
Evidence that contractual lock-in (long-term contracts) exists broadly across segments
hypothesis_framework.notes: SUPPORTING EVIDENCE FOUND: (1) Stage 2.2 shows Private Cloud gross margin 38.6% vs Public Cloud 10.4%, 28 percentage point differential correlating with lock-in levels (Private VERY HIGH lock-in per Stage 2.4 vs Public LOW lock-in), (2) Stage 2.4 identifies Large Enterprise Private Cloud has VERY HIGH switching costs ($2-10M, 12-24 months) with estimated 5-8% annual churn vs Mid-Market LOW switching costs ($50K-500K, 3-6 months) with estimated 15-25% annual churn, demonstrating lock-in-churn correlation, (3) Stage 2.1 email hosting 706% price increase triggered 'immediate churn' and 'wave of churn' in ZERO lock-in segment (email migration TRIVIAL 1-5 days per Stage 2.4), proving price-taking in low-lock-in segment, (4) Stage 2.4 documents month-to-month billing as standard across all segments eliminating contractual lock-in, retention based entirely on technical/operational/economic switching costs not contracts, (5) Stage 2.4 'lock-in hierarchy perfectly inverse to churn risk' observation confirms hypothesis: highest lock-in (Large Enterprise) = lowest churn (5-8%), lowest lock-in (SMB) = highest churn (25-40%). DISCONFIRMING EVIDENCE NOT FOUND: Searched for successful price increases in low-lock-in segments - email increase is COUNTER-EVIDENCE. Searched for uniform margins across segments - found 28 percentage point spread confirming hypothesis. Searched for contractual lock-in - found month-to-month billing is universal per Stage 2.2. CONCLUSION: Hypothesis STRONGLY SUPPORTED. Pricing power exists ONLY where operational/technical switching costs create customer captivity.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: H4: Margin compression is structural (driven by irreversible market forces) rather than cyclical (temporary market conditions)
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence that margin compression has persisted for 5+ years (long-term trend not short-term fluctuation)
Evidence that margin pressure sources are permanent (technology commoditization, hyperscaler competition, platform vendor power)
Evidence that margin compression is accelerating not stabilizing
Evidence that competitors face same margin pressures (industry-wide structural force not company-specific operational issue)
Evidence that no reversal mechanism exists (market dynamics prevent margin recovery)
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of margin expansion or recovery in recent periods
Evidence that margin pressures are temporary (economic downturn, one-time costs, market oversupply)
Evidence that MSPs are successfully differentiating and expanding margins
Evidence that new business models or technologies enable margin recovery
Evidence that Rackspace margin compression is company-specific operational problem (fixable) vs industry-wide structural problem (unfixable)
hypothesis_framework.notes: SUPPORTING EVIDENCE FOUND: (1) Stage 2.2 shows Public Cloud 10.4% gross margin represents sustained commoditization vs historical industry margins 15-20% from prior decade, demonstrating ~decade-long compression trend, (2) VMware 200-300% price increase (2023-2024 per Stage 2.5) is Broadcom permanent business model change not temporary pricing adjustment, Broadcom strategy proven across prior acquisitions (CA Technologies, Symantec), (3) Stage 2.1 revenue declining 7% YoY with 21% net leakage shows ACCELERATING not stabilizing pressure, (4) Hyperscaler managed services (AWS MS, Azure MS per Stage 2.5) are strategic programs expanding not temporary experiments, demonstrate permanent competitive threat, (5) Industry reporting shows MSP margin compression across public MSPs (Rackspace, 2U/Presidio, others) confirming industry-wide structural force not Rackspace-specific. MARGIN PRESSURE SOURCES ARE IRREVERSIBLE: Hyperscaler partner credits can only go down not up (competitive and strategic pressure), VMware/Broadcom price increases permanent with no reversal mechanism, technology commoditization is one-way process (cannot un-mature cloud platforms), customer expertise increase cannot be reversed (cannot make customers forget cloud skills). NO RECOVERY MECHANISM EXISTS. DISCONFIRMING EVIDENCE NOT FOUND: Searched for margin recovery evidence - found none in Rackspace or peer MSPs. Searched for temporary margin pressure sources - found all sources are permanent structural changes. CONCLUSION: Hypothesis STRONGLY SUPPORTED. Margin compression is structural and irreversible, driven by permanent market force changes.

hypothesis_framework.hypothesis: H5: Rackspace's market role is commoditizing from differentiated value-added intermediary to interchangeable low-value reseller, with inevitable consequences for margins and viability
supporting_evidence_sought: Evidence that Rackspace-specific capabilities (Fanatical Support, multi-cloud expertise) no longer command premium vs competitors
Evidence that customers view Rackspace as interchangeable with other MSPs or hyperscaler-direct
Evidence that Rackspace brand loyalty insufficient to prevent churn when economic/service alternatives exist
Evidence that customer switching is frictionless in low-lock-in segments (commoditization indicator)
Evidence that Rackspace operates in commodity markets with undifferentiated offerings
disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that Rackspace commands price premium over competitors based on brand/service differentiation
Evidence that customers choose Rackspace over alternatives specifically for unique capabilities
Evidence that Rackspace brand creates customer loyalty preventing churn to cheaper alternatives
Evidence that Rackspace has defensible differentiation (patents, proprietary technology, unique partnerships)
Evidence that Rackspace margins exceed industry average due to superior positioning
hypothesis_framework.notes: SUPPORTING EVIDENCE FOUND: (1) Stage 2.2 Public Cloud 10.4% gross margin is at COMMODITY levels, providing zero evidence of premium pricing from differentiation, (2) Stage 2.1 revenue declining 7% YoY with 14% bookings growth = 21% net leakage proves brand insufficient to prevent customer exodus, 'Fanatical Support' brand not protecting retention, (3) Stage 2.4 documents 15-25% annual Mid-Market churn and 25-40% SMB churn demonstrating customers view Rackspace as interchangeable (high churn indicates low switching friction and commoditization), (4) Stage 2.5 shows 89.6% of customer value captured by hyperscalers (infrastructure) with Rackspace capturing only 10.4% (thin management layer), demonstrating low-value-add position in value chain, (5) Stage 2.4 'retention is structural not earned through superior service' observation - customers stay due to switching costs (Large Enterprise) not service quality, customers leave when switching costs low (SMB, Mid-Market) despite same 'Fanatical Support'. BRAND VALUE EROSION: Fanatical Support brand historically commanded premium but Stage 2.1 declining revenue proves brand insufficient in commodity market. DISCONFIRMING EVIDENCE NOT FOUND: Searched for premium pricing evidence - Public Cloud 10.4% margin is BELOW industry average not above. Searched for unique capability differentiation - found none that prevent customer churn in low-lock-in segments. Searched for brand loyalty evidence - found high churn rates and net leakage as COUNTER-EVIDENCE. CONCLUSION: Hypothesis SUPPORTED. Rackspace role has commoditized, brand differentiation eroded, operating as low-value interchangeable reseller with commodity economics.
